title: EU consumers back call for more stringent eco-labels on confectionery and other food products - ConfectioneryNews.com
summary: The article discusses consumer preferences for sustainable food products and the importance of transparent eco-labeling to inform consumers about the environmental impact of food.
green_innovation: FALSE: The article does not focus on the introduction of new or significantly improved methods or techniques to reduce negative environmental externalities.
business_innovation: FALSE: The article does not specifically mention a new or significantly improved product or business process that differs significantly from the firm's previous products or processes.
green_product: TRUE: The article emphasizes the importance of environmentally sustainable food products and the need for a universal, independent eco-label for sustainable food products.
green_process: FALSE: The article mentions the need for transparent eco-labeling but does not focus on specific methods or techniques in manufacturing or production to promote sustainability.

title: Nestlé invests £7 million into new hard-to-recycle plastics plant - FoodNavigator.com
summary: Nestlé partners with Impact Recycling to invest £7 million in a breakthrough plastic recycling tech to address hard-to-recycle plastics in food and beverage production in the UK, aiming to improve recycling capacity. The new plant in Durham will utilize a tech to turn hard-to-recycle flexible plastics into reusable pellets for manufacturing new products.
green_innovation: TRUE: This initiative by Nestlé and Impact Recycling fits the definition of green innovation as it aims to reduce environmental impacts by improving plastic recycling processes.
business_innovation: TRUE: Nestlé's partnership with Impact Recycling to invest in a new plastic recycling technology for handling hard-to-recycle plastics in food and beverage production qualifies as a business innovation.
green_product: FALSE: While the article mentions the development of a new plastic recycling technology, it does not focus on the design, manufacture, or use of a specific product that significantly reduces environmental impact throughout its lifecycle.
green_process: TRUE: The introduction of a new plastic recycling technology by Impact Recycling can be considered a green process as it aims to minimize environmental impacts by reducing waste and promoting sustainability in the recycling industry.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities, 325992 - Photographic Film, Paper, Plate, and Chemical Manufacturing, 221310 - Water Supply and Irrigation Systems, 562111 - Solid Waste Collection
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not exhibit greenwashing as it focuses on a genuine effort by Nestlé and Impact Recycling to address plastic recycling challenges in an environmentally responsible manner.

title: PepsiCo pushes entrepreneurial collaboration as 'vital' APAC sustainability strategy - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: PepsiCo launched sustainability-focused accelerator programmes globally, with the APAC Greenhouse Accelerator Programme producing the winner Powered Carbon, which focuses on carbon capture for eco-friendly fertiliser production.
green_innovation: TRUE. The article describes PepsiCo's initiatives to support sustainability-focused solutions and climate actions through its accelerator programmes, contributing to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: TRUE. The article discusses PepsiCo's launch of sustainability-focused accelerator programmes as a new business process to drive sustainability and environmental impact reduction.
green_product: FALSE. The article mentions eco-friendly fertiliser production by Powered Carbon, but the overall focus is on accelerator programmes and sustainability initiatives rather than a specific product design.
green_process: TRUE. The article highlights Powered Carbon's technology for utilizing carbon dioxide to cultivate fungi for eco-friendly fertiliser production, demonstrating a green process to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
greenwashing: FALSE. The article provides information about PepsiCo's sustainability-focused accelerator programmes and specific actions, such as carbon capture technology, without misleading or exaggerated environmental claims.

title: Mars rethinks recipes, ingredients on journey to Net Zero - FoodNavigator.com
summary: Mars Inc. has outlined a net zero roadmap, aiming to halve emissions by 2030 through various strategies including transitioning to renewable energy, developing new ingredients with lower GHG footprints, and using alternative proteins.
green_innovation: TRUE. This is a green innovation as Mars Inc. is implementing strategies to reduce its environmental impact and achieve net zero emissions.
business_innovation: FALSE. The focus of the article is more on sustainability and environmental impact reduction rather than a significant change in products or processes for business innovation.
green_product: TRUE. Mars Inc. is developing new ingredients with lower GHG footprints for snacks and food dishes, as well as exploring alternative proteins, aligning with the definition of green product.
green_process: TRUE. Mars Inc. is optimizing sourcing, processing, and distribution methods to lower emissions, develop novel ingredients, and reduce the environmental impact of its operations, qualifying as a green process.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311352, 311911, 311352, 311119 - Chocolate and Confectionery Manufacturing from Cacao Beans; Roasted Nuts, Peanut Butter, and Other Confectionery Product Manufacturing; Confectionery Manufacturing from Purchased Chocolate; Other Animal Food Manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE. The article does not mention any false or misleading environmental claims by Mars Inc. Instead, it highlights the company's genuine efforts towards sustainability.
